body:
### Problem

Currently the intro text shown when Neovim opens (or upon running `:intro`) has a text alignment issue, in that the output is:

![:intro text as of v0.10](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/37125295/1071ecc7-4af1-440f-bcb7-2a5f63736c34)

```
           NVIM v0.10.0-dev-7acf39dda

  Nvim is open source and freely distributable
            https://neovim.io/#chat

 type  :help nvim<Enter>       if you are new!
 type  :checkhealth<Enter>     to optimize Nvim
 type  :q<Enter>               to exit
 type  :help<Enter>            for help

type  :help news<Enter> to see changes in v0.10

         Help poor children in Uganda!
 type  :help iccf<Enter>       for information
```

This is of course because `strlen("10") == 2`, but also because lines of even length (such as `type  :checkhealth...`) err towards the right.

### Steps to reproduce

`nvim`

or

`:intro`

### Expected behavior

The left- (and probably right-) edges of the `type  :...`s lines to be aligned.

### Neovim version (nvim -v)

0.10.0 commit 7acf39ddab8ebdb63ebf78ec980149d20783fd4b

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

no, 8.2.2434 (didn't have the `type  :help news...` line)

### Operating system/version

Windows 10

### Terminal name/version

Windows Terminal 1.19.11213.0

### $TERM environment variable

(not set)

### Installation

build from repo

comment_data.body:
They could be made to instead err towards the left, e.g. by changing the line (from `static void do_intro_line(int row, char *mesg, bool colon)`):

```c
col = (Columns - col) / 2;
```
to
```c
col = (Columns - col + 1) / 2;`
```

This would fix the alignment of left edges, but at the cost of the rights. The left is certainly more important (if any of this can be described as "important"), but it seems desirable to have both.

It would also move the `Nvim is open source...` line one character to the left, which - though not the end of the world - would be nice to avoid.

Everything would continue to be aligned (without changes) when we go from `v0.1x` to `v1.0`, but would break upon `v10.10` (not a huge deal, particularly as it would be easily fixable, but still).

(Additionally, some people may feel that there is a certain _je ne sais quoi_ about erring to the right rather than the left.)

![:intro text if fixed this way](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/37125295/5f58a5b2-7620-4aaf-a12b-9689c5b7216c)

A different fix is to add a space to each of the other `type...` lines (excluding the `:help news` one), after their `<Enter>`.

This achieves left alignment without sacrificing right alignment, nor affecting any irrelevant lines.

However, we would then have the opposite problem upon reaching `v1.0`.

![:intro text if fixed this way](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/37125295/7ceef7d0-2fec-48ff-8357-53a36ea2b7f4)

Of course, what is likely wanted is to have the extra spaces be added (or not) dependent on the version.

An obvious way to do this would be to replace this (from `void intro_message(bool colon)`):

```c
  static char *(lines[]) = {
    N_(NVIM_VERSION_LONG),
    "",
    N_("Nvim is open source and freely distributable"),
    "https://neovim.io/#chat",
    "",
    N_("type  :help nvim<Enter>       if you are new! "),
    N_("type  :checkhealth<Enter>     to optimize Nvim"),
    N_("type  :q<Enter>               to exit         "),
    N_("type  :help<Enter>            for help        "),
    "",
    N_("type  :help news<Enter> to see changes in v%s.%s"),
    "",
    N_("Help poor children in Uganda!"),
    N_("type  :help iccf<Enter>       for information "),
  };
```

with something like this:

```c
#if NVIM_VERSION_MINOR < 10
  #define NVIM_INTRO_ALIGNMENT_STR ""
#else
  #define NVIM_INTRO_ALIGNMENT_STR " "
#endif
  static char *(lines[]) = {
    N_(NVIM_VERSION_LONG),
    "",
    N_("Nvim is open source and freely distributable"),
    "https://neovim.io/#chat",
    "",
    N_("type  :help nvim<Enter>       "
       NVIM_INTRO_ALIGNMENT_STR
       "if you are new! "),
    N_("type  :checkhealth<Enter>     "
       NVIM_INTRO_ALIGNMENT_STR
       "to optimize Nvim"),
    N_("type  :q<Enter>               "
       NVIM_INTRO_ALIGNMENT_STR
       "to exit         "),
    N_("type  :help<Enter>            "
       NVIM_INTRO_ALIGNMENT_STR
       "for help        "),
    "",
    N_("type  :help news<Enter> to see changes in v%s.%s"),
    "",
    N_("Help poor children in Uganda!"),
    N_("type  :help iccf<Enter>       "
       NVIM_INTRO_ALIGNMENT_STR
       "for information "),
  };
#undef NVIM_INTRO_ALIGNMENT_STR
```

The preprocessor code at the top could be extended to cover potential (far-)future breakages. For example, to cover versions from `v10.10` until `v100.10`(!):

```c
#if NVIM_VERSION_MAJOR < 10 && NVIM_VERSION_MINOR < 10
  #define NVIM_INTRO_ALIGNMENT_STR ""
#elif NVIM_VERSION_MAJOR < 10 || NVIM_VERSION_MINOR < 10
  #define NVIM_INTRO_ALIGNMENT_STR " "
#else
  #define NVIM_INTRO_ALIGNMENT_STR "  "
#endif
```

*BUT*, this doesn't place nice with translations. The `.po` translation files in `/src/nvim/po/` contain entries such as these (from `uk.po`):

```po
msgid "type  :q<Enter>               to exit         "
msgstr ":q<Enter>               вихід з Vim           "

msgid "type  :help<Enter>            for help        "
msgstr ":help<Enter>            щоб отримати допомогу "

#, c-format
msgid "type  :help news<Enter> to see changes in v%s.%s"
msgstr ":help news<Enter>    щоб побачити зміни у v%s.%s"
```

A workaround for this could be to double- (or triple-) up the relevant entries, e.g.

```po
msgid "type  :q<Enter>               to exit         "
msgstr ":q<Enter>               вихід з Vim           "

msgid "type  :q<Enter>                to exit         "
msgstr ":q<Enter>                вихід з Vim           "

msgid "type  :help<Enter>            for help        "
msgstr ":help<Enter>            щоб отримати допомогу "

msgid "type  :help<Enter>             for help        "
msgstr ":help<Enter>             щоб отримати допомогу "

#, c-format
msgid "type  :help news<Enter> to see changes in v%s.%s"
msgstr ":help news<Enter>    щоб побачити зміни у v%s.%s"
```

This seems a very unsatisfying hack.

I'm not sure what's best, and hope there's some other way that ticks all the boxes:

- no/trivial computational cost
- no multiplication of translation entries
- no changes required for `v1.0` (otherwise we'd have to go back and forth upon e.g. `v1.10`, `v2.0`, ...)
- doesn't affect the unrelated intro message lines

Thanks for the attention to detail. But this is way too much exposition for a negligible and debatable "issue". 

I assume you are talking about the "news" line, i.e. a single line that is separate from the other `type...` lines. That line is *centered*. That's intentional.

But if you have a fix that doesn't add a lot of complexity to the code (i.e. a diff of <3= lines of code), send a PR. Otherwise this is "wontfix".

title: :intro text misaligned from v0.10 until v1.0
